title: British house prices fall in July but experts say dip is one-off
text:
British house prices fall in July but experts say dip is one-off British house prices fall in July but experts say dip is one-off HOUSE prices in Britain dropped by 0.6 per cent month-on-month in July but experts said that prices look set to continue growing this year. PUBLISHED: 16:54, Thu, Aug 6, 2015 | UPDATED: 17:02, Thu, Aug 6, 2015 PA WIRE UK house prices dipped in July 
The dip took the average home value in Britain to Â£198,883, according to data from Halifax.Growth in annual values fell to 7.9 per cent in the year to July from 9.6 per cent in June, and is at the weakest level since December 2014, found the lender.However, Stephen Noakes, managing director retail customer products at Halifax, said that "the underlying pace of house price growth remains robust" helped by a shortage of supply.He said: "Continuing economic recovery, earnings growth in excess of consumer price inflation and very low mortgage rates all underpin housing demand. "Supply is highly restricted with the stock of homes available for sale falling further to new record lows."This combination of well-supported demand and tight supply is likely to ensure that house price growth remains relatively strong in the near-term." Related articles Best mortgages deals start to disappear ahead of interest rate rise 
Halifax pointed to recent Bank of England figures showing that the number of mortgage approvals made to home buyers increased by 3 per cent in June, indicating an upturn in housing market activity.An interest rate rise is looming on the horizon, but comments from the Bank of England today suggested that a hike will not take place before next year. Howard Archer, chief economist at IHS Global Insight, said: "Our current forecast is for house prices to rise by six per cent over 2015. "We currently see house prices rising by around five per cent in 2016."Latest data and survey evidence indicate overall that housing market activity is trending up."
